titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Long morning visit from Mr Harris, who communicated to me information of various kinds, of which he has lately heard— I visited my Cellar for the purpose of ascertaining again the extent of the loss suffered by Waldstein’s thefts, and of directing the arrangement and disposition of what remains— Schulz the Baker came this morning, and told me there was more than 99 Rubles due him yet upon his Bills, for which he I produced to him the receipts— He denied having written them. It was so late before I could go out that I was obliged to shorten my daily walk; as by the inflammation in my eye, I was compelled to pass almost the whole Evening in idleness.

2. I returned again to the attempt at early rising, and read this morning by Candle-light, about an hour; after which I took the long walk before breakfast— As I pass’d by the Palace on my return, I saw the last companies of Artillery filing off, from the Parade— After breakfast I had a visit from Mr Fisher— Dined with Baron Blome, and a Company of 23 persons, mostly the foreign Ministers and their Secretary’s. I met here also a Prince Gargarin with whom I had dined more than two years ago, at Count Einsiedel’s— Soon after my arrival here— Mr Bentzon too was of the Company— Baron Blome was very inquisitive whether I was going to England. He told me that the Turks had agreed in the negotiation for Peace, to cede as far as the Siret River; and would have given money; but that there was a difficulty about the frontier in Asia— General Pardo assured me from the best authority— Not Romanzoff, or any of the subaltern’s—that the man, was determined for War— He meant me to understand that he had it from the Emperor himself, which I doubt— But neither of these Gentlemen could tell me, whether Count Nesselrode would or would not be sent to Paris— In the Evening I paid a visit to Mr Bezerra, who is
confined with the gout and erysipelis, ever since the day of the Court, upon the Balcony. I found the Duke of Serra-Capriola with him, and a french emigrant Officer, whom I met last Spring at Count Stedingk’s came in soon after— The Duke was more talkative than ever— I left him there, having myself made a visit of two hours— After I came home we had visits from Mr Harris and Mr Plummer, who purposes going to-morrow for Moscow— Mrs Adams was this Evening very ill again with a sick head-ache; and Charles’s cough returned nearly as severe as it has yet been. I read the 14 and 15. Sermons Vol 4. of the English Preacher on the duty of avoiding to give Offence, and on the incurableness of Superstition.

3. Rose and read again before daylight, and walked before Breakfast; I went out again before dinner; and between household affairs, and trifling away time, I wrote very little, and read scarcely any thing the whole day— In the Evening I read part of the Documents received from America— I sent a Note to Count Romanzoff, requesting an interview with him, and received his answer appointing to-morrow at twelve O’Clock

4. Rose read and walked before Breakfast— And again trifled away several hours of the day. At Noon I called upon Count Romanzoff according to his appointment.— He apologized to me for receiving me in his full dress; which he said was occasioned by his having just received a deputation of Cabardinians.— And I excused myself to him for not being in full dress; at which he took no displeasure. I began by informing him, with my thanks to him for the packets which he had sent me, brought by the Courier from Paris, that I had received in them despatches from the Secretary of State, and a letter personally from the President of the United States— That the President according to the request, which my inability to return to the United States last Summer had made necessary, on my part, had nominated another person to the judicial office, which had been previously designated for me, and had instructed me to remain here; a circumstance which I thought it proper to communicate to this Government; which was one of my motives in requesting the Conference with him.— The Count very civilly expressed his satisfaction at this arrangement, with which he said he was the more gratified, as he had seen paragraphs in the English, and German Gazettes, stating that I was to be removed to England— He had mentioned it to the Emperor, and had thought it probable, as there appeared in England a manifestation of conciliatory dispositions towards the United States. I told him that the paragraphs in the English Newspapers, were probably taken from some of the American papers; where it was much the fashion to announce appointments by anticipation, which never came to be realized— That I had not the slightest insinuation of an intention of the President to remove me to England; but from the tenor of my despatches I had every reason to believe, that no appointment of a Minister to England would be made; unless England should make further, and far more important advances towards conciliation than she had yet made or appeared disposed to make— He said that on the other hand it was understood at Paris that in France; a better Understanding with America was intended, and even professed—that the entire revocation of the decrees of Berlin and Milan, so far as concerned the United States was confirmed, and that with regard to American Vessels, which should arrive in France, there would be little or no difficulty made, as to whence they came; or as to the nature of their Cargoes. That in the general view of the Russian policy, this was very agreeable to him, because it shewed something like a relaxation in favour of Commerce; but he referred me to our former Conversations, in which he had given me his opinion upon the character of the Emperor Napoleon— He did not think that the permanency of any thing to which he should assent, concerning Commerce could be relied upon; every resolution, every act, was the result of an impulse of the moment—the effect of an occasional impression— To day the impression was of one sort, and the measure corresponded with it—to-morrow, the impression would be of an opposite nature, and the measure would follow that too— To make them consistent was not in the nature of the Man— He never looked at Commerce with commercial eyes— He never considered that Commerce was an interest in which all mankind were concerned— He saw in it nothing but the trade of a certain class of individuals— But in truth said the Count, Commerce is the concern of us all— The merchants, are indeed only a class of individuals, bearing a small proportion to the mass of a People— But Commerce as the exchange of mutual superfluities for mutual wants, is the very chain of human association— It is the foundation of all the useful and pacific intercourse between Nations— It is a primary necessity to all Classes of People— The Emperor Napoleon will never see it in this light, and so his Commercial regulations and promises, will never be systematic or consistent— You can place little dependence upon them— I said that his present measures appeared obviously dictated by a political interest— As he saw the situation in which the English Government had chosen to place themselves with respect to America, he was taking advantage of it by assuming a course of an
opposite character— And I believed the British Government alone could prevent his succeeding in it completely. And in order to defeat him they must adopt measures to which they did not appear at-all inclined; and of which I had little hope— He said that he should not dissemble to me, that he had seen the English Newspapers to the 7th: of January, which had been sent to him from Stockholm— That the English Prince Regent’s Speech at the opening of the Session of Parliament was in them— That it spoke of the State of the king’s health— Said nothing at-all about the North of Europe— Mentioned that the affair of the Chesapeake frigate had been amicably arranged with the United-States— That several other topics remained in discussion with them, upon which the most conciliatory disposition was entertained by him— I observed that the profession of conciliatory dispositions had always been sufficiently made by the British Government; but they had been so long the only things we had experienced from England that were conciliatory, that now something more would be necessary to produce the effect; and of this I was sorry to say I could scarcely discern any prospect— The Count said there were some intimations that a messenger had been sent over from France to England— It was even reported that he was charged with overtures for a pacific Negotiation— But that might perhaps be an ostensible measure, to excite the opinion here of a Negotiation between France and England—which in the great and extraordinary armaments said to be now making in France and destined against Russia, might be thought calculated to produce a certain effect here— I said that as to Negotiations between France and England, I did not much believe in them, or in their success if really attempted; but that I had heard there were prospects of War between France and Russia which I lamented— He had mentioned the Emperor Napoleon (The print of him, in all his Imperial accoutrements as Napoléon le Grand, was hanging at the side of the wall, over the sopha upon which we were sitting) and how much was it to be wished, that it were possible the Will, of Peace and Tranquillity could be inspired into his heart! The world might then be allowed to enjoy a little Peace— The Count shook his head, and said No!—it is impossible— Tranquility is not in his Nature— I can tell you in Confidence that he once told me so himself— I was speaking to him about Spain, and Portugal; and he said to me—I must always be going— After the Peace of Tilsit, where could I go, but to Spain— I went to Spain, because I could not go any where else; and this said the Count was all that he had to say in justification of his having gone into Spain and Portugal— And now as perhaps there he is not quite satisfied with his going, he may intend to turn against us; from the same want of any other place where to go— I said that one would think Spain and Portugal still furnished, and were likely long to furnish him quite room enough to go in, without making it necessary to gratify his Passion in another quarter— The Count replied that there was no political consideration whatsoever, upon which he founded a hope that Peace might yet be preserved— But there was a consideration of a different nature which might have its weight, and upon the effect of which he still rested some expectation— It was the scarcity of grain— He understood it was considerable at Paris— I said I had heard the same, and that the price of wheat and flour had much advanced—though not that of Bread, which the Government kept down by payments of their own to the Bakers— He said the scarcity was so great, that there had been recently several riots at the doors of the Bakers, both at Paris and at Lyons— And as large armies could not be put in motion without very large supplies of such provisions, he still hoped that as the months of April and May should come on the inconvenience and difficulty of procuring such supplies for those armies, would ultimately arrest their march—for which however, added the Count, the Circumstances have rendered it proper for us to place ourselves in a state of preparation as we have accordingly done—

I then passed to another subject, observing that it ought perhaps to have been the first with which I should have commenced— The removal of Count Pahlen from the Russian Mission in the United States to that of Brezil— I observed that my despatches from the Secretary of State made it my duty to express to the Emperor, the sentiments entertained by my Government, and their strong sense of the friendly policy constantly pursued by His Majesty towards them, and I had a letter from the President himself mentioning that Count Pahlen had taken leave, and speaking in terms of the highest satisfaction, of his deportment during the whole period of his mission—with the assurance that he had conciliated by it the universal esteem and regard of all who knew him— That it gave me peculiar pleasure to communicate to
him this information, as I was persuaded it must be pleasing to the Emperor— He said it certainly would, and that such a testimonial would contribute to raise yet higher the Emperor’s good opinion of that officer— That his letters had constantly spoken in the highest terms of the treatment that he had received from all Classes of People in America; and that he would quit the Country with the warmest regard for it. I observed that his mission to Brezil would place him in an advantageous situation for observation; not only in regard to that Country itself, but to the Scenes which were passing, in the other parts of South-America—particularly the Spanish Provinces— He asked me whether our Government had taken any measures respecting them, and in what light they were considered, by us; and whether they had any Ministers in the United States— I said I was informed by my despatches, that there were deputies at the seat of our Government from the Province of Venezuela— That the Government of the United States, considered with favourable sentiments the change which was taking place in those Provinces; believing it would prove generally advantageous to the interests of mankind; and that I readily confided to him these views of my Government, because from former Conversations that I had held with him, and from other Circumstances of which I had heard, I thought there was the most perfect coincidence between his views on this subject, and those of my Government— He said they were the same— There was only one doubt left on his mind, which gave him some concern— The People of those Provinces had been kept in such a state of grievous oppression that he was afraid they would in accomplishing their emancipation, exhibit examples of that sort of violence, and those scenes of cruelty, which experience had proved to be too common in such Revolutions— He hoped however it might be otherwise— He had been for opening a free Commerce between them and this Country, which would have implied a recognition of their new State, and he had made a proposition to that effect (in the Imperial Council.) Mais en cela j’ai echoué— The apprehension of those disorders to which I have alluded, prevented my success— On pourra cependant revenir sur cet objet.— I next told him that I had received a letter from Dr Rush, to whom I had transmitted by a safe hand the ring, which his Majesty had directed to be sent to him in his name;—which he had received with the strongest expressions of gratitude, and the wish that the Emperor might be made acquainted with the profound sense which he entertained of the honour conferred upon him by this Present— The Count said he would not fail to make this known to His Majesty who he was sure would be gratified to hear it.— I made my excuses to the Count for the Ladies and myself, for not attending at the Evening party, to which he had invited us for the day after to-morrow; and mentioned to him the painful intelligence we had lately received from our family in America— Upon which he assured me of his sentiments of regret and sympathy, with his customary civility. I returned home, and had a visit from Mr Hazard— At five, I went and dined with Count St: Julien— It was a dinner given to Count Schenk, late Minister from Wurtemburg, who is to take his departure to-morrow or the next day— But half the Company failed; the French Ambassador having also given a dinner this day, and there were only thirteen persons at table.— Mr Laval who was there told me that he should open his house next Tuesday, for which we should receive Cards to-morrow; but I mentioned to him that we should not be able to attend; owing to the news we had lately received from home— He said he wished me to see his house, and particularly some late purchases that he had made of antiques—being the Cabinet of General Hitroff.— He asked me therefore to come and dine with him en petit Comité, next Saturday—which I promised to do.— In the Evening I paid visits to Mr Krehmer, at his new dwelling-house on the Wasili-Ostroff, and afterwards to the Chevalier Bezerra, who is still confined with the Gout; and with whom I again found the Duke de Serra-Capriola— They had the French Courier de Londres, of 7. January containing the substance of the Regents speech to Parliament, which the Duke read with great satisfaction— After returning home, Mr Fisher called and remained with us untill Midnight.

5 My hour of rising is usually correspondent to that of going to bed, and I rose this morning, not before eight, which is this day precisely that of the Sun’s rising. From breakfast time untill four O’Clock afternoon I was engaged with visits from the Chevalier Brancia, Mr: Woodward, and Mr Richards, who came to inform me that he intended to go to-morrow, for Gothenburg, and offered to take any letters so that I might wish to send— Although the notice was so short, I was anxious not to lose the opportunity; but the Evening was occupied like the morning; by a succession of visits from General Watzdorf, Mr Lebzeltern, and Mr Fisher. I scarcely wrote any thing the whole day.

6. The greatest part of this morning I was employed in writing, and intended to have passed the Evening in the same manner; but Mr Fisher came and dined and spent the Evening with us— Mr Smith went to Count Romanzoff’s Ball, given on occasion of the marriage of the young Prince Dolgorucki, with the Princess Gagarin, who came out from the St: Catherine’s school last Spring. The new married couple themselves were not there—the party began at 10 O’Clock in the Evening.

7. From six O’Clock this morning, untill past 12 at Night, with the intervals of my own daily reading, of that of Charles, and of breakfast, dinner, and a walk, (they take of themselves about six hours,[)] I was steadily occupied in writing to the Secretary of State, the President, and my Mother, and making up the packet for Mr Richards— He came to tell me that he should not go untill to-morrow Morning, and by rare good Fortune I had no other interruption through the day— I was fully prepared to dispatch him before I went to bed.

8. Mr Richards called about ten this morning, and I gave him my two packets for America, with a written request that he would forward them from Gothenburg; or if no opportunity should occur there to enclose them to Mr Russell at London, with a request to him to transmit them— I dined at Mr Laval’s with a petit Comité of about twenty persons, with about half of whom I was unacquainted;— General Pardo came with Mr Bellin de Ballu, a great Greek Scholar, after we had sat down to table— Madame de Laval’s Mother, Princess Kazitzky, and her Sister, Princess Beloselsky were there.— Count Maistre, his brother, and son, were also of the company— Mr Laval’s antiques and his pictures were amusing— The Statues are all mutilated, and restored; some well, others indifferently— There are Busts of Cicero—Germanicus in Basalt—and the Emperor Balbinus; of the natural size— A Colossal one, said to be of Diana, and several smaller than life, a Conqueror at the Olympic Games a Sabina—two other Roman Ladies—a Bacchus and Ariadne, upon one stone, Janus-faced—a Pluto seated in his Chair—a Terminus—a rostral column surmounted by a Victory—a Quadriga—without reins or traces a suit of armour sculptured in porphyry— A Roman Consul, remarkable for the drapery of his robe— A basso-relievo, much in the style of the tomb in Count Strogonoff’s Garden— The subject said to be from Homer— Nestor fallen from his horse; and the Greeks, coming to his assistance— But I think them mistaken in this.— A Sarcophagus, or votive altar, inscribed to Julia, the daughter of Augustus, with various sculptures on all its sides, and various other articles, of which I took less notice— The pictures are most of them excellent, but excepting three or four I had seen them all before— The David with the head of Goliah, by Guido struck me more this time than when I saw it last.— The Salmacis and Hermaphroditus, wading through the water by Albans, and a holy family by Fra-Bartolomeo were new to me.— These curiosities furnish one large Saloon—the rest of the house, though fitted up with equal magnificence, had no peculiar recommendation to my taste— It is merely the ordinary princely Style— In the Evening I paid visits at the Chevalier de Bray’s; but found nobody there at home; and to Mr Bezerra, who is recovering from his gout, though still confined to his house— Madame Bezerra went out on a visit, and left me with him— Between 10 and 11. I came home.

9. The Ladies had a morning visit from Mrs Krehmer, and one in the Evening from Mr Harris— And while they were out in the Evening I had visits from Mr Woodward and Mr Blanchard— I read the first three Sermons Vol. 5. of the English preacher; 1. Answering objections against a religious life—by Tillotson—I had read it before. 2. The Divine Government, a joyful truth—and 3. The importance of forming virtuous connections— I also read one Section of the Horae Paulinae— Charles occupies more and more of my time—and already reads with so much facility that I now require of him two Fables of La Fontaine in a day. But he begins to need more constant occupation of his own time; and wants a school which I cannot find for him here.

10. Visit in full dress from Count Schenk who came to take leave, and proposes to go home through Vienna— And from Mr Bentzon, who came and told me that he should go in seven or eight days— That he could come to no agreement here with the Government on account of the American Fur Company, and he wished to obtain through me, a Courier’s Passport— But he is going to Copenhagen, and intends to stop some time at Hamburg— I told him that I should have no despatches for Hamburg; and none for Copenhagen, except such as I should wish to have transmitted to America, and that the only rule I had made upon which I asked Courier’s Passes for the accommodation of Gentlemen was, that they should travel as Courier’s— I told him I thought it would be better for him to obtain a Pass through Baron Blome; but he said he did not wish to travel just at this time as a Danish Courier— I intended to have written this day, but these visits and Charles absorbed it almost entirely— In the Evening I read the Speech of Demosthenes against Phormio, and began that against Lacritus— Both these are upon actions to recover money upon what we should call respondentia— It was lent on stipulations for the shipment of certain merchandize at the risk of the creditor— The vessels were lost in both cases— The debtors pretended in both cases to have ship’d the goods, and thus to be discharged of the debts— The Creditors, for whom Demosthenes writes, insist that the goods were not
ship’d and therefore that the debtors are still chargeable— The contract between the parties is repeated twice in the speech against Lacritus— These Harangues are curious, for the elucidation of the Athenian Laws; but they are otherwise very dull and tedious— Charles who was in my chamber almost the whole Evening, and who this day read four fables interrupted me so much that I could not finish the speech against Lacritus.

11. It was my intention to have written one or two letters this day, but soon after breakfast, I perceived on comparing my book of expenditures, with the Assignation Bank Notes in my draws, that a sum of at least 850 Rubles was missing; and I was employed at least two hours in searching every place where I could suppose the Bills to be, and in recollecting whether I could have made so large a payment, and forgotten to mark it down upon my Book. At last I gave it up as irretrievable, not without strong suspicions that it must have been stolen from my desk or table draw— I rode out in the sleigh to the shops, and from the Fontanka walked round to the lower Admiralty on the Quay— When I returned home to dinner, I found that the child had been suddenly taken very ill, and she continued so, two or three hours— Our dinner was altogether disconcerted— Soon afterwards the Child was much relieved, and slept most of the Evening— I thought at last of examining the pockets of an old Coat that I threw off a week or ten days since, and there I found Bills to the amount of 950 Rubles— They must have been there at least a fortnight, and probably three weeks— When and upon what occasion I put them into the pocket I have no distinct remembrance— The Bills are commonly made up in quires of one thousand rubles each— I must have had a payment of 50 Rubles to make, and have taken it from this quire at some time when a visitor came, and instead of locking it up in my draw have put in into my pocket—and there entirely forgotten it— Such instances of an absent mind occur to me with a mortifying frequency, and in spite of the most anxious and unceasing endeavours to avoid them— I must set them down to the account of a natural defect in my character, which requires the most strenuous efforts of which I am capable to correct it, as far as may be possible— I had a visit this morning from Mr Montreal. Charles was reading with me, frequently during the day and Evening— I finished the Speech against Lacritus, and read those against Dionysodorus, and against Pantenetes— One on a Bottomry Bond—the other on a loan of money for working a Mine—the action was commenced after what is termed at common law an Accord and Satisfaction, and a general discharge given— The Cause therefore in substance the same as that against Nausimachus and Xenopithes; and a part of the Argument too is verbatim the same.— This Evening was the Play, and the Ball at Mr Laval’s, which we excused ourselves from attending

12. Rose before full day-light, and walked my six miles round before breakfast— Afterwards I rode to the shops in the sleigh, and took Charles with me. I had a morning visit from Mr Montreal; and a Conversation upon politics with Dr: Galloway. I dined at the French Ambassadors with a Company of twenty persons—the Ministers of the Diplomatic Corps— It was a parting dinner to Count Schenk— Mr Jouffroy spoke of an ineffectual attempt he had made to obtain the admission of Silesian linens here for re-exportation to America; and of which he was instructed to give me information; as a matter in which I had taken some step—but this was a mistake. the Chevalier Brancia told me that he had received official Communications of the fray and duel between Prince Dolgorucki the Russian Minister, and the Baron de Durand the French Minister at Naples; and the other duel at the same time between Mr Benkendorf the Secretary of the Russian Legation, and the king’s (Joachim Murat’s) Grand Ecuyer—and he related to me the circumstances as he was ordered to represent them; much to the disadvantage of Prince Dolgorucki— He added that he would call upon me in a few days, and shew me the representations that he should officially make here on the subject— The Ambassador conversed quite freely with me on the state of affairs—told me of the occupation by french troops of Swedish Pomerania, and the incorporation of the Swedish Garrison, into the French army; which he said laughing was following the example of Frederick 2.— And of the Swedish Counter-measure of confiscating debts due to french subjects—including their loans in Holland. He spoke with contempt of the Prince Royal (Bernadotte’s) late report to the king—said he hoped, people would not now charge them (nous autres—the French) with having fixed the election of Prince Royal upon him— Said he supposed he was afraid of the Nation— But then he ought to have bargained with them, and have refused to accept if they would not honestly and faithfully come in to the Continental system— He also said he did not yet despair of preserving Peace between France and Russia; but he should unless something was very soon done— He wished they had sent Nesselrode— He had not urged it for it was a proposition of their own— But now they said it would look like making advances—what then?— Prince Kurakin was sick— Nesselrode had been the Secretary of the Embassy— Now he was the Emperor’s Secretary— They had given him “un galon de plus,” but what did that signify? why not send him? he might be the more acceptable for the added lace— Certain it was
that something must be done, and that very soon, or the worst might happen— I had much Conversation with General Pardo, too; but that was upon Homer, Demosthenes and Cicero— He insists that the Iliad and Odyssey are not Works of the same author, and that the last five Books of the Iliad are not of the same hand with the rest— In the Evening I paid a visit to Mr Bezerra who is still confined with the Gout. I found Dr: and Mrs Creichton with him. While I was there Count Nesselrode and his Bride paid them a short visit— They were married on Sunday last— Miss Gourieff has found a husband. Prince Trubetzkoi, and young Count Maistre were also there in the course of the Evening.— On returning home, I found Mr Fisher, who had dined with the Ladies— The infant and Charles, are both quite unwell.

13. Lessons of temperance multiply upon me— I totally lost my Night’s rest— The second time that this has happened to me this Winter— Whether it was the excess—or the Coffee after dinner—or the uneasiness in regard to both the children with which I went to Bed—I did not close my eyes— But I rose little before the Sun, and walked the round— Morning Visits, from Mr Raimbert, Mr Hazard, and Mr Fisher with Mr Chastelgué a frenchman, and Mr Wollers a German from Archangel, and from America. In the Evening I read in Auger, the Speeches of Demosthenes against Phenippus and against Evergus and Mnesibulus— As in many other instances the names of the persons for whom the Speeches were composed are not known—the first is for an Exchange of Estates, according to one of Solon’s Laws, which must naturally have occasioned much litigation— There is an Oration of Isocrates on the same question— The second is against two Witnesses, whose testimony had occasioned the complainant to lose his Cause in another suit— Harpocration thinks this a Speech not of Demosthenes but of Dinarchus.

14. The weather is very fine, with 14 degrees of Cold by Reaumur— I walked the long round before Breakfast, and to the lower admiralty before dinner— The rest of the day I was engaged in writing letters to be sent by a person who goes with a Courier’s Passport obtained by Mr Bezerra— I sent him the letters in the Evening.

15. I continue to be engaged so great a portion of my time in the most insignificant trifles of household economy, that it has become irksome to me, in the extreme— The closer I make my inspection the more and more I discover of imposition, and of pillage, in every shape— Yesterday on visiting my Cellar, I found twenty bottles of Wine had disappeared from it within a fortnight, beyond those that are accounted for— This day I weighed some Coffee sent from two different places, and found it short weight, about one pound to forty.— Last Night a Candlestick and Candle were stolen from our Entry— It is the third or fourth thus lost this Winter.— My weighing, brings me again to examination of the weights and measures of this Country— I called at an English Mathematical instrument maker’s to enquire if he could make me an arshine, with the English and French corresponding measures, but he could not— I went also to a tin man’s to enquire if he had any measures of capacity; but he had none except a cup which he said would hold a pound of Water— I dined at Mr Raimbert’s, with Mr Chastelgué, Wollers, Mr David and Mr Smith who went with me, and Charles, who was particularly invited by Mr Raimbert— Mr Montreal shewed him, and then gave him to bring home a Magic Lantern— We had it exhibited over again after we came home; and finished the Evening with Cards—

16. There is something in these enquiries about weights and measures, singularly fascinating to me— The research about the Russian measures of capacity led me to look into the Manuel des Poids et Mesures, for the French measures under the new system. I took the dimensions of the Litre, for the measure of liquids, and finding that the Litre for dry measure though of the same capacity was of different form, I fell into calculations of the capacity of cubic and cylindric vessels, and from one question to another spent the whole day, profoundly occupied with this subject— I take such an idle pleasure in it, that when once involved in it I have not at times of leisure vigour of self-controul sufficient to extricate myself from it— I did not indeed suffer it this day to intrench upon my hour of reading before breakfast, or upon Charles’s lessons— He read in the course of the day four fables—but my daily walk was a little shortened— My Journal, gathering the fourth day of arrears; and my other reading of the day reduced to a very few pages of the Horae Paulinae— I shall indulge myself further still in these inquiries—endeavouring however to keep my propensity towards them under better regulation— Mr: Smith dined and spent the Evening abroad.

17. Mr Harris called on me this morning and invited me to dine with him; I went to the shops in further search of weights and measures— I found there was an imperial manufactory of iron weights at Alexandrofsk— And a Manufactory of Scale-beams at Tula— But I could not procure a good pair of scales, and only got a one pound iron weight— Dined with Mr Harris
the company were Baron Rall, whom Mr Harris introduced to me, Mr A. Severin, Mr Plessig, Mr Krehmer, Mr Pepin, Mr Mollivo, and two other Gentlemen whose names I did not discover—with Mr Ecky and young Mr Harris— Mr A. Severin told me of his collection of Coins, which he invited me to go and see— I paid an Evening visit to the Chevalier Bezerra, whom I found still confined to the house, but able to walk— On returning home I received a letter and some English Newspapers brought by Mr Norman—who arrived this Evening from Gothenburg— There was also a letter for the Chevalier de Bray.— We had Cards.

18. I called on the Chevalier de Bray and delivered to him the letter I had received for him last Evening— He invited me to dine with him this day— Mr Norman had called upon me before I went out— After a long conversation with Monsieur de Bray, I went to the shops, in further pursuit of weights and scales, and finally took up with such as I could find— Returned home only to dress and went to dinner at the Chevalier de Bray’s— Mr Laval and Mr Harris dined there—and a professor of the University of Dorpat, with whom I had much conversation respecting that Institution— Mr Laval had got a small silver coin or medal of Balbinus, given him by a friend, and perfectly resembling his bust, with which he was in extasies of delight— He had also a copper coin with the head of Augustus Caesar, resembling though not so strongly, another of his Busts.— The Chevalier de Bray gave me a copy of his Tour in the Tyrol, of his own Edition, which he told me was not so good as the Edition printed at Paris— I spent an hour with the Chevalier and Madame Bezerra—then half an hour at home; and finally about two hours at the French Ambassador’s Ball, where I conversed with several persons; but particularly with General Pardo, who made very light of the surrender of Valencia, and General Blake with his army— Pardo is one of the first classical scholars in Europe— A military man thoroughly versed in the Science of War—with a fine taste for the Arts; a brilliant imagination, much eloquence in conversation, and withal the weakest head, the most abandoned to his feelings, and the memory the most treacherous to itself that I ever knew— He had often spoken to me of Blake, as a sort of military prodigy— To night he told me that he knew him perfectly well—that he Pardo, had formed him— That he was an excellent garçon but no General— His heroes now are Ballasteros—l’Empecinada, Mina and Mendizabal— He considers the patriotic Cause as so firmly established, that he makes no scruple to speak of it as his own— He says we shall be successful— We have such and such places in our power— We have defeated Victor at Tarifa, meaning by we the Spaniards in Arms against king Joseph, whose Commission and Credentials are his only acknowledged titles at this Court; and by whom he has been loaded with dignities and Offices; not to forget a blushing ribband, which the General takes no displeasure in wearing— Count St. Julien was looking through his glass at the dancers, and lamenting that the sex in Russia was not handsome— Mogul faces—Néz Camus—et des Bouches qui se moquent des Oreilles— Oh! at Vienna— Not a Guinguette of chambermaids, but would shew more handsome women, than all Petersburg could produce— The Chevalier Brancia told me that he had called on me this morning to shew me his correspondence respecting the affair of Prince Dolgorucki at Naples—and he promised to call again— I came home about one in the morning.

19. Had long morning visits from Mr Harris and Mr Woodward; and Charles renewed his lessons of reading repeatedly.— But the day and evening untill near midnight was absorbed in attempting to ascertain the precise length of the new French measures by comparison with the English— Of the only Books that I have—Ricard, Paucton, Dubost and Webster no two precisely agree— And they almost all disagree even in the statement of a geographical degree in English miles—the slightest inaccuracy in the measure of length necessarily occasions a corresponding one in all the other measures, in the weights, and in the value of Coins— I came at last to the conclusion of taking the Statement in which Paucton and Dubost agree, and considering 9386. french pieds de Roi as equal to 10000 English feet, and of forming the comparison of the new measures by that proportion. I wearied myself with calculations, but without coming to any satisfactory result.

20. Morning visit from Mr Woodward— I gave a great part of this day to my enquiries— Looking into Paucton’s Metrology, I found in it much curious information and a multitude of new objects of further research— This subject spreads itself as I advance untill I shrink from its magnitude, and the time which it must consume. The knowledge that I do acquire by it comes also excessively slow—and I no sooner think I have settled a point definitively than I find it staggered by a different Statement— My walk this day was again shortened; but in the Evening I read the Speeches against Callicles and against Eubulides, with which the 5th: volume of Auger’s Translation concludes; and also the first of the sixth Volume, against Polycles— One is a defence of an action for damages, for overflowing the grounds of Callicles—then in support of a contested right of Citizenship, for Euxitheus. And lastly a suit to recover from Polycles, expences and charges incurred, by Apollodorus as fitter out and Commander of a vessel in the service of the State— Polycles had been chosen as successor to Apollodorus, but had refused or evaded taking command of the vessel to relieve him.— Cards to finish the Evening.

21. Morning visit from Mr Montreal, who brought me a French Translation of the addition to the manifesto respecting Commerce, issued for the present year— Besides the hours that I gave to Paucton, I read this Evening the Speeches for the naval-Crown, in behalf of Apollodorus; and against Nicostratus, as a debtor to the public Treasury— I began the one against Timotheus, but was called away to Mr Harris and Mr Woodward, who paid us Evening visits, and kept me untill near Midnight.— I find in Paucton an Article concerning the Russian Measures and weights, uncertain like every thing else that I have met with on the subject. He insists that the Russian Arsheen is more than 28 inches English measure, in which he is certainly mistaken—he makes the pound equal to 7710 grains poids de mark which is eleven grains Troy more than its real weight.— I pursued the questions started in my own mind respecting English weights and measures— Neither Paucton nor Ricard can satisfy them— Ricard says the Statute, mile, was fixed by a Statute of Henry 7. at 5280 feet or about 69 1/6 miles to a degree— But what is the standard of the foot?—and what is the standard of a degree?— We sat down to dinner for the first time without candles; since we returned to the City.

22. Visit from Mr Fisher with Mr Forrester a young American from Salem— My day was occupied again like many of the past— The question of this day was to ascertain the extent of the Earth’s Circumference— The only English Book I have at hand to consult in this case was Morse’s Geography— There I find it stated at 25.038 Miles—which divided by 360. makes the degree = 69.55 miles.— But by the admeasurement of the Meridian between Dunkirk and Montjouy—the quarter of the earth’s Circumference was definitively settled to be 5.130.740 French Toises (Toise du Perou) the 1/10,000000 part of which is the Metre of the new French system.— Taking then the English foot as .9386 of the French pied de Roi the Circumference of the Earth is = 131193011 English feet or 248.47.25 Statute Miles and gives 69.02 to a degree.— The quarter of the Circumference is 32.798252.7 English feet, and the ten millionth part of it is 3 feet 3. inches 358 tenths of an inch.— In the Evening I finished the Speech against Timotheus; and began that for Phormis; where the Orator appears against the same Apollodorus, for whom he composed the four preceding harangues— They are both relative to Banking accounts and very dry— In the preliminary reflexions of the 5th: Volume Auger says that he will at the beginning of the sixth make some general remarks on the speeches contained in it; and say why he had put them together— But there is no preface to the sixth Volume— Harpocration questions whether the Speech against Timotheus was by Demosthenes; but Auger thinks it authentic— We had Cards.

23. I consulted Borel’s Tables of the Russian weights, measures and Coins, to see how he states the Metre— He has the arshine right, at 28 English inches; but he makes 71.19. Metres = 100 Arshines and 140.48 Arshines = to 100 Metres— The first of which makes the Metre = 39.331. English inches; and the second to 39.334— This difference in the fraction is itself considerable, and would amount to five inches in a Mile— But the Metre as I have found it is 25/1000 or 1/40 of an inch longer than either of these measures gives it; and 1/25 of an inch added to the shortest of these would only make the measure as given by Webster— This would make a difference of at least five feet in a mile— I drew diagrams of the French Demilitre and of the decilitre, according to the dimensions prescribed by the French law— The Capacity of the first is 30.509. cubic english inches, and of the second 6.1. cubic inches— I was then curious to compare them with the capacities of our glasses and bottles in common use— I measured the dimensions of a tumbler, and calculated its Contents; after which I adjourned this pursuit untill to-morrow— My morning reading, my Journal, Charles’s lessons and my walk continue— In the Evening I read three Sermons Vol. 6. of the English preacher— On having our Conversation in Heaven, and on Prayer— Also several Sections of the Horae Paulinae—

24. Began the morning with experiments of the weight of water and the capacity of our Bottles, glasses and Decanters— I find the weight of Water corresponding with the principle of the French System near enough for practical purposes, but I have neither weights, nor scales nor measures adequate to obtain a precise result— Neither is the water or its temperature that which the precise experiments would require— I began a letter to America however, and in the Evening finished reading the Speech for Phormio— It is strongly tinctured with Athenian manners— Phormio the Banker had been the Slave of Pasio the Banker, and father of Apollodorus. Pasio had himself been the slave of the previous holder of the Bank— Pasio, at his death liberated Phormio, and left him by Will, his Bank and his wife— Demosthenes says this was a common practice— There were naturally prejudices against these slaves turned into Citizens and their Children, against which prejudices Demosthenes reasons by the usual arguments. Their principal compensation for doubtful Consideration was their wealth, which it seems Banking made in a manner certain. It is strange and very dishonourable to Demosthenes that in this Speech he reproaches Apollodorus in terms of bitter invective with the very processes against Timotheus, Callippus and others, of which he himself had written the Arguments— It seems he really was the lawyer of both parties—and wrote for whoever paid him.— Cards.

25. Morning visits from Mr Bentzon, and Mr Harris. Mr Bentzon informed me that he should not go away so soon as he had expected. He has resumed his negotiations here on the part of the North-American fur Company, which he thought had entirely failed— But some new propositions have been made to him— Mr Harris appeared to have a great curiosity to know what Mr Bentzon was doing.— I was disappointed in my expectation of having time this day to write. I began to read regularly through Paucton’s Metrology— He says that what first turned his attention to the subject was a passion for the improvement of agriculture, which he resolved to study in Books— He soon found that he could understand nothing in them without accurate ideas of weights and measures— The study of these took place of his first pursuit—the accessary became the principle— He postponed probably forever his agricultural enquiries, and produced his Metrology. This is too much the progress of all my studies; but I shall never produce a Metrology— In the Evening I read the two Speeches against Stephanus the Witness— They are in the name of Apollodorus, and are as much or more against Phormio, than against Stephanus— The marriage of Phormio with the mother of Apollodorus is here mentioned as a deplorable and disgraceful thing— The speeches have all the marks of Demosthenes’s manner— Plutarch speaks of this double dealing and fraud with too much mildness of censure— Mr Smith dined with Mr Harris— In Evening we played about an hour at Cards— Reaumur’s thermometer last Evening was at three degrees above freezing, and this Evening is at 12. below 0.

26. The morning being clear though with about 15 degrees of Cold by Reaumur, I rose and walked my round before Breakfast— Saw the Sun rise as I was on the Quay, opposite the marble Palace— After breakfast Mr Woodward called upon me, and I went with him to look at some Crates of English confiscated white ware, which are selling there at Auction— Mr: Consolat met us there.— Mr Smith took Charles out with him to the Subscription ice-hills— In the Evening I read further in Paucton; and find in him a strong recommendation of the use of decimal fractions and logarithms for the facility of practical calculations— A familiar and ready use of logarithms, is one of the things that I have neglected to acquire—and I have not been aware with how much convenience they may be applied to the ordinary purposes of business— I am aukward in the management of them— I read also the Orations of Demosthenes against Callippus (in the name of Apollodorus) and against Neaera— The accuser in this last is Theomnestus, who after a short introduction, requests the Judges to permit him to call upon Apollodorus to speak for him; and accordingly Apollodorus pronounces the remainder of the Speech— The Accusation was that Neaera, being a foreigner, had married an Athenian Citizen—and the law condemned every foreigner in such a predicament to be sold as a slave— There is a long and diffuse history of Neaera’s life and amours; for she is represented as a common Courtezan— The motive for prosecuting her alledged, both by Theomnestus and Apollodorus is the injuries they have received from her husband Stephanus— This pretence recurs in many Speeches of Demosthenes, and often as in this case leads him to narrations having no other connection with the cause— Revenge was avowed as a legitimate justification for pursuing an enemy by public prosecution— This speech is of doubtful authenticity— But Auger thinks it genuine— Demosthenes appears in it as a witness. I closed the day earlier than usual.

27. The cold and fine weather continues— I rose before the dawn of day, and walked an hour and a half before breakfast.— I had counted upon a long day for writing, but was disappointed— I walked again before dinner, and in the interval busied myself much with my weights and scales— Wrote a little— Mr Fisher dined and spent the Evening with us— I finished reading Auger’s translation of Demosthenes—the Speech against Theocrinus, and the Oration in honour of the warriors who fell at Cheronea, close the work— Auger considers them both as spurious— The first because it contains frequent mention of Demosthenes, and occasionally in a manner not complimentary, but rather harsh—and the second because he thinks it not worthy of the Orator— I am not sure that Auger’s conclusions are right in either case— Demosthenes might speak of himself slightingly to avoid suspicion as author of the speech against Theocrinus— Nothing is said of him in the speech which could have been very offensive to him. Theocrinus is accused by Epichares, for having compounded a prosecution that he had commenced against Micon— Or for prosecuting without foundation Micon, who was a merchant— There was a Law, adapted to either horn of this Dilemma— And Epichares, just of age, prosecutes Theocrinus, at the urgent instigation of his father, whom Theocrinus had prosecuted, as a debtor to the Treasury, and obtained against him a judgment for ten Talents— Auger says that some antient Critics suppose the Speech to have been composed by Dinarchus— The funeral Oration, is a demonstrative discourse and naturally of a different cast from the contentious character of all the rest, but its sentiments are entirely congenial to those of Demosthenes— He certainly did deliver a funeral Oration upon that occasion, and this Oration is published among his works— It is not equal to the funeral Eulogies of Isocrates— But the Demonstrative Oratory was the Element of Isocrates, as the Judicial was that of Demosthenes— I think I shall never again read through the Speeches of this Orator in private Causes— The public Orations can never be too much studied. Auger’s Translation, is altogether an excellent work— It is complete, excepting an Erotic Oration, which he omitted from scruples of delicacy.

28. I called at the house of the brothers Livio, and received payment of the Bill drawn by Mr Poletica, which they had accepted the 17th of last Month— Mr Livio told me that the exchange was very advantageous to me— He must have thought I knew nothing about Exchange— I told him that in comparison with what it would have been two months ago it was less disadvantageous, but he would acknowledge the present exchange was much above par which he admitted— I also called upon the Chevalier de Bray and had some conversation with him on the aspect of affairs— He is full of the expectation of a War with France; as indeed at this time is every body— My walk was shortened— The whole Evening I was engaged with Charles, endeavouring to teach him in a form of amusement the first elements of arithmetic— I had no time left, either for reading or writing.

29. I had heard it said by Dr: Galloway that in cold and calm weather here, the smoke from the chimnies instead of ascending, was often depressed, and settled over the City, and I witnessed this effect in my walk before breakfast this day— The atmosphere was perfectly clear untill the body of smoke formed from the fires in the City had settled together, constituting a thick fog, which obscured the Sun, totally, and continued three or four hours— It was not entirely dissipated untill past Noon. I had a morning visit from Mr Montreal, and evening visits from Mr Fisher and Captain Boit— I wrote a little, but Charles engrossed a great part of my time.

Day. My own health, and that of my family has been this month generally restored— I have resumed the rule of rising as early as the Circumstances will admit— But I can seldom have the house shut much before Midnight, and of course find it seldom practicable to rise earlier than 7. in the Morning— Without being regular to this hour, I have risen by it on the average of the Month— In fair weather I walk the six miles round before Breakfast, which we now have before or about 10.— I read as usual, write my Journal, and hear Charles read— Weights, Measures and Visitors with an hour’s walk before dinner occupy me untill 5. in the afternoon;—when we dine—from seven untill ten in the Evening, I read or hear Charles, or talk with him to amuse and instruct him— Then have an hour or two of Cards or Conversation in the drawing room; and from eleven to twelve find the time for retirement— I have sometimes dined and sometimes spent the Evening abroad— More seldom have Evening Company at home.— Too much of my time is still wasted.
